head.title: General Instrument Up As New Interest Arises

LEAD: The shares of the General Instrument Corporation rose today on the expectation that a new offer might arise to top the friendly bid of $1.6 billion made earlier this month by Forstmann Little & Company.

The shares of the General Instrument Corporation rose today on the expectation that a new offer might arise to top the friendly bid of $1.6 billion made earlier this month by Forstmann Little & Company.

General Instrument, a New York-based electronics concern, disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that a second company had expressed interest in receiving financial and other information. The party's identity was not disclosed.
The company's shares rose 75 cents each today, to $46.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, after reaching a new high for the year of $47.125.

Forstmann Little's offer, made on July 2, is $44.50 a share in cash, but General Instrument's stock has traded above that level since the deal was announced, signaling that traders expect a higher bid.

After being reached by the third party on Wednesday, a move that General Instrument said was unsolicited, a special committee of the company's board directed managers to provide the information, subject to an agreement to keep it confidential, the filing said.
E. Magnus Oppenheim, the president of E. Magnus Oppenheim & Company, an New York advisory firm, said Forstmann's bid ''left a lot to be desired.'' He added, ''There is room for a higher bid.''
Other analysts said they were not surprised by the indication of interest because General Instrument's cable television equipment business is an attractive target for acquisition.
''There is probably more money than deals out there, and they have an attractive core business,'' said Robert Anastasi of the Robinson Humphrey Company in Atlanta.
A spokesman for Forstmann Little, a private investment firm, had no immediate comment on the filing.
